column14: The manufacturer assigns Vendor Analyte Code to their devices, while the Laboratory creates test result codes for the tests they provide.
column15: The manufacturer assigns a Vendor Analyte Code to their devices, while the Laboratory creates test result codes for the tests they provide.
column17: Fix typo

column14:
Vendor Analyte Code = 1067 (Gluc) is mapped in the LIS to:
LIS Test Result Code = 123 - Random Glucose
LIS Test Result Code = 456 - Fasting Glucose
LIS Test Result Code = 789 - 1 Hour Glucose
LIVD Mapping Vendor Analyte Code = 1067 (Gluc) suggests:
Based on vendor comment [comment], vendor result description [result] A, vendor specimen description [specimen] "cerebrospinal", LOINC axes => 2342-4
Based on vendor comment [comment], vendor result description [result] B, vendor specimen description "urine", LOINC axes => 63382-6
Based on vendor comment [comment], vendor result description [result] C, vendor specimen description "serum/plasma", LOINC axes => 20438-8
Consequently, most appropriate mapping:
LIS Test Result Code = 123 - Random Glucose
LOINC Code = 2342-4
LIS Test Result Code = 456 - Fasting Glucose
LOINC Code = 63382-6
LIS Test Result Code = 789 - 1 Hour Glucose
LOINC Code = 20438-8
column16: This example is not correct - the vendor comments refer to different specimen, while the LIS test codes refer to different timing / other parameters about the Glucose test- sugget to update to showcase the specimen difference instead
column17: Fix example so it is consistent with vendor comments

column14: Antoher example may be that an IVD test for serum glucose could map to one LOINC code considering a mass concentration (e.g. mg/dL) or another LOINC considering a substance concentration (e.g. mol/L).
